replies.bodyText:
I believe the best practice is not to provide Javadocs for @Override methods, since it will be mostly duplicative of the content of the interface/base class being overriden.
The JavadocMethod checkstyle has this a default setting:

Javadoc is not required on a method that is tagged with the @OverRide annotation.

In a few place in this code base, we have the @inheritDoc Javadoc directive on @Overriden methods.
A guy on StackOverflow goes on:

I studied this problem during my PhD and found that in general folks will never be aware of the extra information in the overriding version if they are invoking through a supertype.

Holy Cow. Talk about "Diving Deep!"

Naming --
I've been working hard for us to avoid having any FooUtils classes (by name).
AsyncUtils could end up being abused in the future, and have all kinds of executors, schedulers, etc., in it., over time.
Would it make sense to call this class Disposables?  Rx does have a class by this same name.
Disposable disposable = Disposables.fromCancelable(cancelable);

Alternately, we could call it:
Disposable disposable = Cancelables.asDisposable(cancelable);
